data.title: Top Women in Communications Awards Luncheon 2023
data.meta_description: Feb. 28, 2023 - Come celebrate with Ragan and your peers this year’s lineup of Top Women in Communications. We’re rolling out the red carpet on Tuesday, Feb. 28 for a special luncheon at the City Winery in New York City to celebrate the 2023 class of fearless female communicators.
data.text:
Senior Vice President & Chief Communications Officer

Eli Lilly and Company

Evolving her team, Kathryn Beiser represents Eli Lilly and Company with passion

A veteran in the field of PR, Kathy Beiser has proven year after year that she has the intellect, intuition and bold direction required to succeed in the industry. Her work spanning many areas has earned her the recognition of her cohorts, and makes her a sure fit for Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Hall of Fame.

Ever since Kathy Beiser has joined Eli Lilly and Company (Lilly), she has uplifted and supported her teams’ objectives with steadfast leadership. Lilly creates medicines by pioneering discoveries utilizing chemistry, biotechnology, and genetic medicines, rendering even the most difficult diseases manageable. As the senior vice president and chief communications officer, Beiser’s reach has gone far in helping others.

In her time at Lilly, Beiser has seen important and pivotal changes to the company. She helped to shape the global corporate communications team, reorganizing and refining to create a more agile force better equipped to handle challenges. She’s developed a multitude of campaigns to drive organizational culture and encourage performance, including corporate reputation programs.

No stranger to the comms discipline, she oversees several responsibilities including, public relations, media relations, issues management, internal communications and executive communications. Additionally, she’s served as a corporate spokesperson and overseen intricate financial transactions. Whenever issues or complexities arise, she manages them efficiently and keenly, due to her focus on learning about areas of the business outside communications.

“Learn the business, learn the field, learn everybody else’s job,” she advises young communicators. “Because you’re going to be talking about all of those things. Be a great communicator, that’s fine. But the real value comes when you have a seat at the table, and you’re talking about the business, you understand the business, you are better counselor

Outside of Lilly, she’s served on the board of Bright Pink, a nonprofit aiding women in the trials of breast cancer, and on the board of Break the Cycle, another nonprofit that aims to end domestic violence and facilitate healthy relationships among teenagers. A member of the International Women’s Forum, it’s clear Beiser is a champion of women inclusion in and out of the workspace.

As she looks to the future of the industry, it’s the people around her that give her the most hope.

“I’m really excited about the caliber of people joining our profession,” she said. “I’m seeing more and more people who have a really integrated approach to communication, who are not afraid of technology, who are excited about that interconnectivity.”

Congrats to Kathy Beiser.

CEO

Ruder Finn

Ruder Finn’s CEO Bloomgarden honored with Hall of Fame status

Dr. Kathy Bloomgarden, CEO, Ruder Finn is described as a visionary. If you follow her career journey, it will be clear why. She’s being inducted into Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Hall of Fame.

Dr. Kathy Bloomgarden likely wasn’t planning a career in PR. As a matter of fact, she was busy getting her doctorate at Columbia University in political science and Chinese studies, as she thought it would serve her well in a career in government. But, fate stepped in. While doing research in a back office at Ruder Finn, the PR firm founded by her father David Finn, Bloomgarden found herself immersed in data and statistics related to Ruder Finn’s research efforts. The rest, as they say, is history.

Or, history in the making. American and Chinese businesses were working together, and Bloomgarden with her background in Chinese studies and fluency in Mandarin, expanded Ruder Finn to China. She also had a deep interest in the healthcare industry and set her sights on biopharma practices. With her back room interest in data and analytics, she has ensured that Ruder Finn stays ahead of data-driven emerging technologies, and has expanded the agency into Web 3.0 and blockchain. Today, Ruder Finn is one of the leading independent public relations agencies with offices across 3 continents including the U.S., Asia and Europe.

“When I look to the future of what’s next in communications, I am most excited about the adoption of new technologies to further enhance our storytelling, ability to analyze data, and capacity to understand each other further,” Bloomgarden said in an interview. “As digital transformation disrupts every business model, path-breaking communications is essential to building trust and navigating risk in a fast-changing marketplace.”

In her current position as CEO for 8 years running, Bloomgarden has overseen significant growth by the agency; in 2020, thanks to the agency’s work in pharma and technology, Ruder Finn had double digit growth domestically. What’s more, recognizing the need to connect authentically with the Hispanic community, Ruder Finn acquired Comunicad, a multicultural agency with 30+ years of expertise in cultural intelligence. And, with video streaming dominating media, Ruder Finn acquired and integrated film company Osmosis Films.

Her management style is hands-on by adapting to employee changing needs, treating employees like family, mentoring and concern over personal wellbeing. Ruder Finn established a TechLab incubator so that employees can explore new technologies, lead town halls, and practice reverse mentoring, as well as participate in yoga and cooking classes.

“My father, and Ruder Finn’s founder, David Finn stood by the mantra ‘Just because you don’t know how to do something, doesn’t mean you can’t,’” Bloomgarden said in an interview. “This is a mentality that I like to adopt when taking on new challenges, and is my greatest advice for young people, and women in particular, getting into the field.”

Outside of Ruder Finn, Bloomgarden is involved in The Foundation for the National Institutes of Health (FNIH), is a long-standing member of The World Economic Forum and the Partnership for New York City, which focuses on re-energizing the city after the pandemic slowdown.

Says Ruder Finn’s Chief Innovation Officer Michael Schubert, “I can think of no person better suited to bring David Finn’s legacy into the future. Kathy embodies David’s core values around internal culture, stakeholder capitalism, and creative disruption, but she adds a global perspective and passion for reinvention that has supercharged RF to new levels, not only driving extraordinary growth, but injecting one of the great legacy PR companies with the energy, agility and innovation power of a unicorn start-up. She’s an inspiration and it’s an honor to work with her.”

CEO

Brodeur Partners

Andrea Coville builds Brodeur Partners to new heights

By diversifying its services and strengthening existing public relations, Andrea Coville has helped to shape Brodeur Partners into a globally recognized communications agency. Her accessibility to her team members and willingness to grow, listen and evolve has earned her induction to Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Hall of Fame.

As CEO at Brodeur Partners, Andrea Coville has facilitated a reliable and purpose-driven business that consistently engages clients. Brodeur Partners is a full-service communications agency focusing on PR with a complete range of services including media relations, content creation, strategic messaging, paid and earned social media. In her time as CEO, Coville has encouraged a multidisciplinary approach to business, adding public affairs, DE&I, digital marketing, creative, purpose and sustainability.

She’s overseen the acquisition of multiple companies, and has formed integral partnerships with the American Cancer Society, Deloitte, NFL, Mastercard, and Dana Farber Cancer Institute, to mention a few.

Her steadfast leadership has remained focused on staying relevant in a changing industry, to which she’s managed to achieve and maintain for years. She directs her employees with compassion and purpose, emphasizing and encouraging healthy workspaces and balanced approaches to business. Coville created wellness programs for employees, and has raised money for charities.

She’s also taken the time from her busy work schedule to share her experience with others by speaking at American University, the Harvard Dynamic Women in Business Conference, Wharton Women in Business, Simmons College, Syracuse University’s Newhouse School of Public Communications, Harvard’s Kennedy School, Google Author Talks and more.

Working with so many people early in their careers, Coville’s advice is to “find your fit.” “Look for a great culture,” she said. “It’s the single most important thing.”

Coville has remained a grounded, accessible leader; available to every one of her employees, checking in with staff and ensuring everyone under her employment has what they need to succeed.

She also keeps an eye to the future and what’s next in communications. “I’m really excited about the use of video and its role in storytelling in both paid and earned media,” she said. “And I think we have just begun to see the impact that sustainability and inclusion will have on brands, particularly as Gen Z realizes its economic power and influence.”

Congrats to Andrea Coville.

Vice President, Communications, Customer Experience, Retail

CVS Health

Yanique Griffin-Woodall inducted into Women in Comms Hall of Fame for career spent in B2C service

Yanique Griffin-Woodall has spent her extraordinary career focused on serving customers in a variety of B2C communications roles. From her early days of agency work to roles with Home Depot, 1-800-FLOWERS, Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. and Avon, her focus has always been on delighting customers.

“I am passionate about the customer experience,” she says.

She currently serves as vice president, customer experience and communications at CVS Health, where she focuses on creating narrative strategies that help further the retail and customer experience.

“It’s our responsibility, as a retailer, to make sure that we’re delivering on our promise to give you a stellar experience,” Griffin-Woodall says.

Outside of her corporate experience, Griffin-Woodall contributes to education in the field. She earned her own bachelor’s degree at HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY and her master’s degree in Corporate and Public Communications from Seton Hall University and a master’s business administration from the Michael J. Coles School of Business at Kennesaw State University. She is an adjunct assistant professor in George Washington University’s Graduate School of Political Management and is an adjunct professor at Hofstra University’s School of Communi­cations. She also is the 2023 IPR Chair for The Institute of Public Relations.

When asked for her advice for young women looking to enter the communications profession, she offered three pieces of wisdom. First, be curious about everything. Second, to learn about not just communications, but also the business side of the equation. And finally, but most importantly, to give yourself “space and grace.”

“I am so thankful for the honor of being inducted into the Women in Communications Hall of Fame,” Griffin-Woodall says.

“I’ve had the opportunity to work with some of the most amazing people in the industry, communications and retail, and business in general,” she continues. “I’ve had the opportunity to learn from them and partner with them. And now I get the opportunity to share this recognition with amazing honorees alongside me. How lucky am I?”

Congratulations to Griffin-Woodall on a career spent in service to the customer.

SVP and Chief Communications Officer

Cisco Systems, Inc

Cisco’s Poveromo inducted into the Hall of Fame

With two decades in executive roles in the ever-changing technology landscape, Maria Poveromo recognizes the increased importance of the CCO position in an evolving business landscape. She’s an inductee to Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Hall of Fame. SVP and CCO, Cisco Systems, Inc.

Maria Poveromo is no stranger to Silicon Valley and its technology bellwethers, holding executive roles at IBM, Adobe and currently Cisco. As senior vice president and CCO for Cisco Systems, Inc., her take on the evolving role of the CCO has been to elevate the position: To actively help companies navigate business, economic, cultural and societal trends.

Poveromo leads with compassion and a vision for agile and resilient communications both internally and externally. She believes, “Brands that communicate with emotion, compassion, and facts get rewarded.”

Empathy is a critical skill for corporate comms pros, you must understand each stakeholder’s mindset, values, needs, and wants to craft successful strategies and content. When people feel empathy from a company, they’re more likely to trust it, forgive it and advocate for it.

Indeed, her advice to new communicators, especially women, is to be authentic about their own strengths — including empathy. As a young communicator, she was told she needed to be colder and more callous to succeed.

“That felt inauthentic to who I am; and conversely confirmed in me that I can lead effectively with compassion, empathy, and kindness,” she said. “Also, recognize the value you deliver as an advisor, culture leader, and brand ambassador. Your work will shape how stakeholders view, feel about, and interact with your organizations.”

Among her many accomplishments at Cisco in the last year, she’s navigated supply chain issues, the war in Ukraine, increasing cybersecurity threats, continued social justice concerns, effects of the Great Resignation, and mounting inflationary pressures. As an example, with the war in Ukraine, Poveromo coordinated with leaders across the over 70,000-employee company to ensure visibility into Cisco’s position and response. In a matter of hours, her team stood up a hub of critical materials for employees, customers and partners. It was a quick and unified response delivered with empathy and clarity and inspired confidence in the company’s decisions.

Under Poveromo’s watch, Cisco’s reach with top media outlets has increased by 27%, and Cisco has consistently been rated as the #1 Great Place to Work in multiple countries. She has pledged to reach beyond the basic DE&I expectations and implementations at the company, embedding DE&I principles into team culture worldwide, leading to standardized inclusive hiring practices in partnership with HBCUs to nurture an early-career talent pipeline. Team members are encouraged to participate in employee inclusive communities — such as PRIDE, Black Connected Professionals and Connected Asian Affinity Network — as well as join trainings and talks to learn about allyship, identity, and other topics critical to furthering social justice.

She’s optimistic about the future of communications and the role communicators have in building a better world.

“I’m excited to see how communications organizations will use collaboration tools to more deeply understand and engage with stakeholders, and to deliver even more relevant and meaningful content,” she said. “I am also intrigued by AI and believe this new frontier will require some of our best thinking, particularly around reputation management. And, certainly, I am heartened by the role communications has played in advancing ESG in each of our organizations and in our communities.”

Outside of Cisco, Poveromo serves as vice chair and a board member for Second Harvest, a food bank in the San Francisco. She also leads the Women of Cisco-San Jose community and is a champion of DEI education Cisco-wide. She’s a member of Equal Rights Advocates, a San Francisco-based organization fighting for gender justice.

Further credit includes being named one of the 25 Smartest Women on Twitter by FastCompany.

Former Senior Vice President Corporate Public Affairs

Cox Communications

Leigh Woisard’s distinguished career in public affairs recognized with Hall of Fame induction

Leigh Woisard has dedicated her professional life to communicating issues that matter. From early work in communications for lieutenant governors and congresspeople to more than two decades with Cox Communications as vice president and later senior vice president in public affairs on both the governmental and corporate side, she’s dug into the complex issues that all organizations must navigate to be a positive influence on society.

But it’s an agency internship that she counts as one of her most formative experiences.

“It’s a really good opportunity to learn a lot fast. I parlayed those skills into working in more of an elected official, government capacity, and those skills really translated,” says Woisard.

In her years in the field, she’s noticed two big shifts in the industry. First is a transition away from media relations toward employee communications. “Companies have really begun to put a high premium on communicating with their employees. I’ve seen a proliferation of employee comms departments within really big companies, and I think that’s a great thing,” she says.

Additionally, the explosion of data has changed the industry too. “On the one hand, that access to information and data has been a godsend in the sense that you can plan and check your progress because we have access to so much information. The downside of that is with so many data points, we have to be careful that it doesn’t become a distraction.”

Today, Woisard does public speaking on communications — especially how women in communications can build their brand. And she has plenty of advice for up-and-coming women in the field.

“I think it’s smart to develop your identity in a specific area and decide, ‘what do I want to be known for?’ And then be very intentional about building your brand around that.”

She noted that the very things we often do for our clients are the things we can often neglect to do for ourselves.

“Women are notorious for shying away from self-promotion,” she says. “And the result that I hear from a lot of women is they get to a certain level in their career, they’ve had a certain amount of success, but then they start to stagnate and find it hard to get to that next level.”

We congratulate Woisard for reaching the pinnacle of her own career, and earning a spot in Ragan’s Women in Communications Hall of Fame.

Senior Vice President, Corporate Marketing and Communications

Ameresco

Ameresco’s Dillon reenergizes corporate culture, solidifies corporate reputation

Leila Dillon’s passion for innovative cleantech solutions, purpose-driven work and maintaining Ameresco’s core values makes her an honoree in the Bridge Builders category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

During her now four-year tenure as senior vice president of corporate marketing and communications for Ameresco, a cleantech integrator and renewable energy asset developer, owner and operator, Leila Dillon has been able to expand on the company’s business goals, leading to the implementation of multiple complex projects. Among those, communication efforts for floating solar at Fort Bragg, an Army training site with over 50,000 active duty personnel; selection as an energy partner in Bristol City Leap, an aggressive citywide energy infrastructure overhaul to help the UK City of Bristol reach zero carbon emissions by 2030; and the groundbreaking of Kūpono Solar Project, a complex solar and storage project at Joint Base Pearl Harbor Hickam that will provide energy security for over 10,000 homes on the island of O’ahu.

Steadfast in keeping the Ameresco name top of mind, under Dillon’s purview, the company had its first-ever earned national broadcast feature, highlighting its work helping the City of Chicago complete a citywide LED streetlight conversion project, which led to multiple full-length features that aired on NBC News Now and MSNBC.

Dillon, a champion for purpose-driven work, has worked to ensure that ESG is at the forefront of many company initiatives. She’s a founding member of Ameresco’s ESG Ambassadors program, implementing and supporting programs to properly track Ameresco’s progress toward its long-term goals. Ameresco Ambassadors was named an “ESG Team of the Year” finalist in Ragan Communications’ 2022 CSR Awards program. Living its mission “to deliver energy efficient and renewable solutions that enable a low carbon future,” Dillon also oversees the company’s ESG reports, which have been awarded distinctions from the 2022 Hermes Creative Awards and the American Business Awards.

Congrats to Leila Dillon.

Director, Global Communications

Project Management Institute

Karen Flanagan builds department from the ground up at Project Management Institute

Karen Flanagan’s actions have earned her recognition in the Bridge Builders category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Karen Flanagan is no stranger to hard work, and it shows. When she joined the team at Project Management Institute — a not-for-profit professional membership association for the project, program, and portfolio management profession – eight years ago as director, she had to build a department from the ground up.

Flanagan worked to educate leaders on the value and need for communications, created a foundation and strategic framework to draw in changemakers or new potential members to PMI courses. In her role, Flanagan has grown her team to oversee not only external, social media, executive comms, but also regional communications and internal and chapter/membership communications.

Continuing to grow since 2021, the PMI global communications function now includes six regional communicators who oversee the organization’s brand building efforts in 15 markets across seven regions. Flanagan’s team also manages the more than 50 social media channels in six languages that serve more than 3 million project professionals across the world.

“Her leadership in developing the global function and oversight of chapter and member communications, has been key to helping PMI navigate major world events from the past year including the war in Ukraine and the passing of Queen Elizabeth II,” says PMI Senior Vice President Allison Szeliga, who nominated Flanagan for the award. “This has made headway among the PMI community to see PMI as a connected global player.”

The PMI social follower count has grown nearly 32% since the regional expansion of communications. Flanagan also established a Center of Excellence to assist in the delivery of integrated content and social amplification. Under Flanagan’s management, her team has maintained above industry engagement on social channels and majority share of voice against competitors all while increasing PMI’s impressions by 40%.

Congrats to Karen Flanagan.

Corporate Communications Director

Penske Transportation Solutions

Penske Transportation Solutions’ Harmsen drives the messaging to 40,000+ associates

Kimberly Harmsen is in the driver’s seat as senior corporate communications manager of Penske Transportation Solutions. She leverages her PR experience to build bridges with internal and external stakeholders alike to advance the strategic goals of the organization. She’s an honoree in the Bridge Builders category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Not unlike Penske’s mission to keep the world moving forward, Kimberly Harmsen keeps the company’s communications internally and externally moving forward. She joined Penske Transportation Solutions, which provides transportation, supply chain and technology solutions, in 2017 as a public relations manager but quickly became indispensable during COVID as she led the rapid response team and quickly shifted to head up internal comms as well. Today, she leads a team of three comms specialists.

Responsible for communicating to a diverse, decentralized workforce that includes corporate associates, professional drivers, maintenance technicians and warehouse associates at more than 1,350 locations, she puts a major focus on the future of the business — from sustainability and emerging technologies to the company’s commitment to diversity and inclusion.

Additionally, she takes the lead in communications for human resources, including benefits, staffing, associate engagement and professional development, and supports Penske’s response to natural disasters and other emergencies.

Partnering with senior leadership is key to some of her other comms responsibilities, as she handles all communications needs related to acquisitions — from onboarding new associates to leadership remarks and press releases. She also manages relationships with non-profit organizations, such as Women in Trucking and Truckers Against Trafficking, as well as valued customers and business partners.

Some notable accomplishments in the past year:

Managed all communications for several acquisitions, which transitioned hundreds of associates and thousands of assets to Penske.

Supporting the transition to a post-pandemic work environment.

Developing unified sustainability messaging by breaking down siloes and assembling data from more than a dozen internal teams, including sourcing, facilities, fuels, sales and maintenance.

Led communications campaigns for new HR programs, including launching business resource groups for diverse associates, an appreciation campaign for corporate and field associates, and a company-wide associate survey.

Securing national recognition for three Penske female executives.

Congrats to Kimberly Harmsen.

Head of Corporate Marketing Communications

Ortho Clinical Diagnostics

Ortho Clinical Diagnostics’ Hayes leads the charge to evolve the brand

Lisa Hayes has defined and executed robust comms strategies to establish Ortho Clinical Diagnostics as a world-class brand in in-vitro diagnostic solutions and services to hospitals, clinical laboratories and blood banks around the world. She’s an honoree in the Bridge Builder category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

No stranger to the healthcare industry, Lisa Hayes has been leading the comms charge for the evolving $4 billion global brand Ortho Clinical Diagnostics, a subsidiary of QuidelOrtho. In just her two years since joining the company as head of corporate marketing communications, Hayes has been busy, to say the least. First, she built her team from the ground up and led the communications needed to take the company from private equity to publicly traded.

To do that, Hayes launched a global brand refresh with a new website featuring improved content and capabilities. She led the charge in modernizing the company’s MarTech stack to enable valuable data, and now is an integral part of leading the company’s integration with Quidel. She has been working to develop the story of QuidelOrtho and overseeing the change management across the company.

Hayes leads a combined corporate and global product marketing communications team, including internal and external corporate communications, public relations, global digital marketing, creative services and global marketing communications. With this team, she works to bring the company’s story to life to deepen customer relationships.

To all of her initiatives, Hayes brings a collaborative leadership spirit and promotes personal and professional growth for her team and the greater organization.

Congrats to Lisa Hayes.

Managing Director, Head of Communications & Brand Experience

ING Americas

ING Americas’ Kanter brings hybrid workplace culture to life

Melissa Kanter joined ING Americas at the height of the pandemic and has become the instrumental force in building a hybrid workplace culture. She’s an honoree in the Bridge Builder category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

No easy feat to join as managing director, head of communications & brand experience, ING Americas, in June 2020, just three months into the pandemic. But Melissa Kanter did just that and has proactively paved the way to revive and nurture culture — termed Hybrid Mode by the financial institution — in a post-pandemic environment.

The shift required Kanter and her team to introduce a new internal campaign focused on how employees can “collaborate, connect and grow” to drive business. The approach included in-person, digital, written and virtual experiences that reflect ING’s strong “orange culture” resulting in a shared sense of community and continuity. To do that, Kanter incorporated more personal and authentic messaging from senior management, a new internal visual identity to drive internal engagement efforts, virtual and in-person learning and engagement experiences, and a suite of resources focused on best practices for staying connected while prioritizing mental and physical wellbeing.

With Hybrid Mode underway, Kanter also focused efforts on supporting ING’s local communities as head of the company’s charitable committee. The committee works to align local charitable efforts with the interest of ING’s employees and global community investment approach. The committee identified key pillars of focus — from financial health and sustainability to training and education and DE&I. It also introduced a signature charitable program focused on raising funds for employees impacted by the war in Ukraine, including raising more than $8,000 to support the child of a Ukrainian employee who needed emergency surgery.

Other highlights include:

Connecting with the existing sponsorship of the CityParks Green Girls program, a science-and-STEM-based afterschool and summer program.

Allocating funding to more than 20 local organizations and securing grants from ING’s global community investment fund for programs with Minds Matter and NPower.

Encouraging employees to donate over 2,000 volunteer hours to support organizations, including New York Common Pantry, City Parks Foundation and Habitat for Humanity

As a further bridge-builder and foster of culture, Kanter has worked with employees at various levels to revive employee resource groups.

Congrats to Melissa Kanter.

VP of Executive Communications

Genesys

Genesys’ Alice Nagle leads the way for employee communications

Calm under pressure, Alice Nagle helped Genesys navigate uncertain times. Nagle is an honoree in the Bridge Builders category in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Alice Nagle joined Genesys, a global leader in cloud customer experience and contact center solutions, in 2020 in the middle of a pandemic and with no executive communications function.

According to Director of Executive Communications Sylvie Tongo, who nominated Nagle for the award, Nagle is a “master at demonstrating empathy in action, guided by clear and transparent communications.”

“Her strategic communications experience and executive presence were critical during a recent corporate restructuring,” Tongo says. “Her skill at thinking through the strategy holistically, advocating for empathetic actions, and the importance of communications yielded clarity among employees amid a very challenging and uncertain situation.”

The conflict in Eastern Europe created uncertainty for employees in the region, so Nagle collaborated with business leaders to lead a project ensuring consistent engagement with teams in the region.

“Alice ensured alignment and clarity of ALL communications to both internal and external stakeholders when the decision to shut down operations in Russia was made,” Tongo says. “Her efforts resulted in zero negative feedback surrounding the winddown from employees, customers, partners, or vendors.”

During her time as vice president of executive communications at Genesys, Nagle has helped shape company culture by spearheading projects to elevate the company’s storytelling, thought leadership and strategic vision. By defining key communication objectives and developing main stage content in collaboration with her team, results achieved at these events have increased 5% to an overall 98% satisfaction rating for the Genesys internal new year kickoff event, and a segment satisfaction rating from 93% to 96% for the flagship annual customer event.

Under Nagle’s leadership, Genesys invested in an internal employee portal, “OneGenesys,” with executive sponsorship across departments. The portal launched in August 2021 and one year later, the intranet has more than 140 sites and more than 86% of employees visit the intranet monthly, beating industry benchmarks by 27%.

“Employees are responding and taking action at rates well above industry averages for internal communications,” Tongo added. “The portal powers 60,000 searches with less than 1% error – a significant employee productivity boost.”

Nagle’s innate ability to connect people through the practice of strategic communications is just one of the reasons why she is an honoree in the Bridge Builders category in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Congrats to Alice Nagle.

Director, Marketing & Communications

Core & Main

Core & Main’s Noonan leads the expansion of its corporate communications team

Jennifer Noonan is no longer a solo act at Core & Main. She rallied the company’s leaders, expanded her team and, ultimately, the company’s growth. She’s an honoree in the Bridge Builders category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Jennifer Noonan certainly knows how to test the waters. As a solo strategic comms leader at Core & Main, a specialized distributor of water, wastewater, storm drainage and fire protection products, when she began in 2017, she charted a course to success by building out a team internally and externally. Today, her team has more than doubled in size, handling both marketing and communications for over 4,000 associates, 300 branches and $5 billion in revenue.

To do that, she first had to establish trust with top leaders to build a solid brand, vision and mission for the company, and now making sure that the brand, vision and mission are consistent in everything the company communicates internally and externally.

Growth at Core & Main has been achieved organically and through acquisitions. Noonan has supported the integration of new teams and new associates into the Core & Main culture.

Additionally, Noonan has established a great relationship with both the functional/support teams as well as the “boots on the ground,” which Core & Main calls “the field.” Meeting people where they have been as important to Noonan as being in the boardroom. This was especially crucial during COVID, connecting safety and human resources policy and procedures and safety measures.

Noonan did the same most recently with a national sales and leadership meeting that assembled the comms team and representatives of all parts of the business to ensure the experiences, presentations, and rewards were meaningful to all involved.

Congrats to Jennifer Noonan.

Vice President Program Communications and Partnerships

Kimmel Cultural Campus

Leslie Patterson-Tyler’s focus positions Kimmel Cultural Campus as partner in performing arts, community

Leslie Patterson-Tyler’s actions earn recognition in the Bridge Builders category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Called a “natural to this position,” Leslie Patterson-Tyler, vice president of program communications and partnerships on the Kimmel Cultural Campus has her finger on the pulse of Philadelphia as she leads comms for one of the region’s most impactful performing arts center.

In her role, Patterson-Tyler led a season-long partnership with Taller Puertorriqueño, Inc. – a community-based cultural organization known as The Cultural Heart of Latino Philadelphia –with a toy drive, artwork display and donation. She also facilitated a partnership renewal this fall.

Patterson-Tyler’s relationships have helped grow the Kimmel’s annual holiday celebration and, in the fall of 2021, her team produced its yearly promotional video differently with a changed message to specifically encourage church populations as it was safe to return to the campus post COVID-closure.

This spring, Patterson-Tyler led planning of an annual Soulful ‘Thank You’ luncheon for pastors and directors. Through relationships created during this event, Kimmel has continued to foster relationships within the church community by acting as a yearly supporter of Wawa Welcome America Gospel on Independence. Patterson-Tyler also is an active member of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. and thus facilitates events with local sororities as well.

These are just some of the highlights that led to Patterson-Tyler’s nomination.

Kudos to Leslie Patterson-Tyler.

Chief Marketing Officer

Media.Monks

Kate Richling, Media.Monks’ first CMO, brings marketing teams together with a common goal

Kate Richling’s efforts earn her a nod in the Bridge Builders category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Since the Media.Monks brand launch last year, Chief Marketing Officer Kate Richling has helped integrate more than a dozen companies under a single name, a unitary structure, disrupting the traditional agency landscape. In her role, Richling manages marketing, PR, awards, and internal communications across 31 S4Capital markets. Media.Monks is the digital-first operating brand of S4Capital plc.

In 2022, the company added three brands and 2,000+ staff, and achieved 198 shortlists and 223 award wins. Under Richling’s lead, Media.Monks has earned recognition across all its offerings including AdExchanger’s Top 50 Programmatic Power Players, Webby’s Production Company of the Year, Campaign’s Social Media Agency of the Year and placement on Adweek’s Fastest Growing lists. Media.Monks also was featured in two Forrester Waves for the first time.

Sarah Comstock gives voice to employees, leaders, and company Ally Financial

Comstock’s efforts earned her a nod in the Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Champions category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Diagnosed with congenital hearing loss at the age of 28, communications professional and passionate storyteller Sarah Comstock believes it is important to give a voice to others.

In Comstock’s own words, “You can tell a lot about a company’s culture by how they talk to their employees. At Ally, we’re intentionally conversational – we bend the traditional rules of corporate communications, evoke pop culture references, and create content – even when tackling difficult topics, like systemic racism – that’s approachable. It’s all reflective of the culture of inclusion we fiercely protect.”

In her role as executive director of corporate communications, Comstock leads the development and execution of Ally’s internal communication strategy and is the voice of the enterprise. Some innovative and informative programs she has created include: Ally’s EqualAlly Human Campaign, a weekly digest of news clips and happenings called BriefAlly, an enterprise-wide competition called FutureFest, and Ally’s intranet. In 2020, Comstock and her team served as the voice for the company on health and safety, social injustice, mental well-being, and vaccine education.

In addition to her work with Ally Financial, Comstock is a member of Impact 100 Metro Detroit, volunteers with Catch A Fire and Big Brothers Big Sisters, and has mentored numerous students through Wayne State University’s First Generation Mentorship Program.

“Ally’s employee engagement surveys have never been stronger – with employees commenting on how connected and well-informed they feel about all the evolving and unexpected events happening in the world,” says Kathie Patterson, Ally’s chief human resources officer, who nominated Comstock for the award. “Sarah has been and continues to be the catalyst for creating connections.”

Kudos to Sarah Comstock.

Global Vice President, Communications and Reputation

AB InBev

Kate Laverge brews up a heady mix of diversity initiatives at AB InBev

She’s spearheaded DE&I programs in volunteering, communications and leadership development, building the bench for the brewing company’s future and earning her honors as a Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Champion in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Kate Laverge’s commitment to diversity, equity and inclusion began long before her current position as global vice president of communications and reputation at AB InBev, among the world’s leading brewers. During her 12 years at Paramount, where she led communications and culture for international business, Laverge championed programming for Paramount’s annual Inclusion Week and the launch of international employee resource groups, among other key initiatives.

In her current role, Laverge serves as the communities pillar lead in AB InBev’s Global DEI Council, which is chaired by the CEO. She has spearheaded projects like Dream Big Day, the company’s global volunteer day designed to activate a global network to empower local communities and use the company’s scale, knowledge and unique capabilities to solve significant community problems.

She also has partnered with Global Diversity and Inclusion VP Jaclyn Senner on the development of a holistic DE&I-focused communications strategy that includes an editorial strategy celebrating and communicating the DE&I work of colleagues around the world. The effort resulted in DEI-focused features in AB InBev’s newsroom, the company’s weekly On Tap Newsletter and a leadership DEI training program.

But there’s more. Laverge also has championed the company’s new global diversity, equity and inclusion platforms, a straightforward communications framework designed to encourage leaders to speak about DE&I issues credibly and confidently. The platforms — “An Inclusive Future,” “An Empowered Future” and “An Equitable Future” — build on AB InBev’s philosophy, “We Dream Big to Create a Future with More Cheers,” an approach designed to integrate DE&I into the company’s mission.

To manage brand engagement with DE&I topics in a rapidly evolving environment, Laverge partnered with internal stakeholders to develop a social issues framework designed to clarify how, when and why brands should engage on social advocacy. Under her leadership, AB InBev’s brands have taken stands on issues relevant to key communities, joining efforts with partners to say “No to racism,” “Love is love” and “Together in pride” around the world.

On top of all this, Laverge is a mentor and champion of diverse talent in the organization, building a pipeline for the next generation of leaders.

Congrats to Kate Laverge.

CEO

The Levinson Group

Molly Levinson takes on big fights in support of social issues

She’s advocated for women’s equal pay, a fallen journalists memorial, LGBTQ+ rights and more, making her a Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Champion in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Molly Levinson, founder and CEO of The Levinson Group (TLG), has served as an advisor to the world’s top companies and their leaders. As an advisor on major social impact and public interest engagement campaigns, she’s worked on some of the most notable and headline-grabbing issues over the last decade.

For example:

Levinson led TLG’s efforts supporting the U.S. Women’s National Soccer Team’s pay discrimination lawsuit against the U.S. Soccer Federation, winning a $24 million settlement and new collective bargaining agreements guaranteeing equal pay. Her work for the USWNT was featured prominently in the HBO Max documentary “LFG,” which premiered at Tribeca in June 2021.

In partnership with Nobel Peace Prize laureate Nadia Murad and her organization Nadia’s Initiative, Levinson advocates for survivors of gender-based violence and communities in crisis, with audiences including heads of state and the United Nations.

Since founding TLG, Levinson also has worked to champion, protect and honor journalists at home and abroad. TLG is the founding strategic communications and engagement partner to the Fallen Journalists Memorial Foundation, and Levinson serves on its board of advisors. The Foundation’s goal is to build the first memorial honoring fallen journalists and press freedom on federal land in Washington, D.C.; since TLG’s involvement, it has secured more than $10 million in contributions and grants, as well as a siting endorsement near the National Mall from the Secretary of the Interior.

Finally, Levinson has positioned TLG on the front lines of the fight to protect LGBTQ+ rights, leading communications efforts for plaintiffs and their legal counsel challenging the controversial Florida House Bill 1557, also known as the “Don’t Say Gay” law. TLG’s efforts produced top-tier media coverage, including a highly moving Good Morning America interview featuring plaintiff Zander Moricz and lead attorney Roberta Kaplan.

Congrats to Molly Levinson.

Senior Vice President

United Way of the National Capital Area

Phillips highlights the important work of United Way NCA

Her crucial campaigns showed off how United Way serves communities in need throughout the D.C. metro area. Nedelka Tejada Phillips is an honoree as a Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Champion in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

United Way of the National Capital Area (United Way NCA) champions equity for all people across the greater Washington, D.C. metro area. As senior vice president of United Way NCA, Nedelka Tejada Phillips oversees marketing, branding, communications and resource development for the $24 million annual gross revenue charity.

With her 12-person team, Phillips focuses on diversifying the organization’s revenue streams and transforming its growth model. Much of her work is focused on equity issues in low- and moderate-income communities, amplifying United Way NCA’s efforts to attract and retain corporate and community partners, allowing United Way NCA to bolster programs through financial capacity and volunteers.

Under Phillips’ leadership in the last 12 months, United Way NCA launched the Thrive United 365 brand, which focused on health equity, and the award-winning Practice Equity campaign, which places equity and social justice issues at the forefront of the United Way NCA mission. The campaigns allowed Phillips to show how United Way NCA is serving these communities as a racial/social justice issue, and how crucial the work is for the region.

As a result of Phillips’ marketing communications campaigns, United Way NCA earned an uptick in social media engagement, with Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and LinkedIn profiles collecting 94.7K+ total impressions; a steady stream of earned media achieved an audience reach of 336.1 million (Nov. 2021-Oct. 2022).

Phillips’ aim is to drive increased support for community impact initiatives through grants, relationships with individual employees, and meaningful opportunities for engagement and connection with the community and fellow supporters.

Ultimately, United Way NCA completed its 2022 fiscal year with strong wins and new opportunities to continue growing, diversifying and sustaining revenue. The fiscal year closed reaching 93% of its fundraising goal for all revenue raised through the United Way NCA, and 89% of its target for revenue raised and designated to United Way NCA — numbers that reflect a year-to-year increase of 4% in net revenue from fiscal year ’20-’21.

Congrats to Nedelka Tejada Phillips.

Global Lead Pan Asian Network (PAN) People Business and Resource Group

Bristol Myers Squibb

Jennifer Rasing leads the charge for inclusivity at Bristol Myers Squibb

Bristol Myers Squibb’s Jennifer Rasing’s commitment to an inclusive workplace has led to key initiatives, spanning across many facets of BMS culture. Her actions have earned her recognition in the Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Champions category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Jennifer Rasing has spent her 20+ year career dedicated to the biopharmaceutical industry and currently leads the Pan Asian Network (PAN) People & Business Resource Group for Bristol Myers Squibb (BMS), a global biopharmaceutical company.

Throughout her tenure at BMS, Rasing has pushed to drive equitable advancement and outcomes for all by fostering inclusion and ensuring every colleague is valued, respected and feels a sense of belonging. Through programs like Asian Voices and Cultural Spotlight, Rasing has helped create a safe culture that allows colleagues to speak up and contribute to how the company moves forward.

Rasing spent many years as a clinical trials scientist, which is why she recognizes that health disparities and the social determinants of health in communities around the world need to be addressed to drive a more equitable society. An example of this: Last year, PAN partnered with many AANHPI organizations and thought leaders to address health disparities, raise awareness, accessibility and encourage more diverse clinical trial populations.

“Jennifer [Rasing] is a change champion, promoting PAN and awareness of Asian and Pacific Islander issues by speaking and driving the development of groundbreaking programs throughout the organization,” says Devynne Kapocsi, senior manager of corporate marketing, who nominated Rasing for the award. “Her commitment to an inclusive workplace that values diverse viewpoints has led to key initiatives, spanning across many facets of BMS culture.”

Kudos to Jennifer Rasing.

VP of Communications at Mastercard Latin America & Caribbean (LAC)

Mastercard

Mastercard’s Janet Rivera-Hernandez’s passion for digital and financial inclusion is priceless

Janet Rivera-Hernandez drives growth through strategic communications and reputation management at Mastercard. Her efforts have earned her acknowledgement in the Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Champions category of Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Janet Rivera-Hernandez, vice president of communications at Mastercard Latin America and Caribbean (LAC), believes in the importance of financial inclusion as a path toward prosperity and inclusive growth in LAC. Mastercard is a global technology company in the payments industry.

With more than 15 years of experience at Mastercard, Rivera-Hernandez leads a team of 16 communicators across LAC (75% women, 20% LGBTQI+, and 5% men) and oversees the work of agency partners. She supervises all communications in support of the company’s employee engagement efforts in three languages (English, Spanish and Portuguese) in a region with 1,200+ employees across more than 15 countries with over a dozen offices. Rivera-Hernandez works to amplify the company’s inclusion efforts through programs such as Tech4Good and the Partnership for Central America.

By leveraging traditional and digital media, in addition to a robust program of industry events across the region, Rivera-Hernandez is able to push the mission forward among employees, consumers and partners. In early 2022, she and LAC’s communications team defined a strategy to position Mastercard as an employer of choice, using core aspects of Mastercard’s culture.

In 2022, Rivera-Hernandez’s continued work with the Gender Balance Steering Committee for the region and Mastercard’s Girls4Tech program in Latin America inspired girls to pursue education in STEM.

For International Women’s Day, Rivera-Hernandez led “Growing Together is Priceless,” an internal campaign, featuring more than 30 employees and department leads across the region, who contributed their personal stories to the company’s message and then amplified those on social media.

These are just a few of the reasons why Rivera-Hernandez’s hard work, experience and passion are priceless to Mastercard.

Congratulations to Janet Rivera-Hernandez.

Senior Director, Public Relations & Executive Communications

Century 21 Real Estate

Erin Siegel leads CENTURY 21’s efforts to influence the national conversation around real estate

Siegel was key to a documentary on COVID’s impact on home buying; she also spearheaded a program for Latina entrepreneurs. It’s led to her being named a Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Champion in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

CENTURY 21 has been an iconic name in the real estate industry for more than 50 years, and as senior director of public relations and executive communications, Erin Siegel has been instrumental in pushing its leaders, affiliated brokers and agents to influence the real estate conversation at a national level (for example, by positioning CEO Mike Miedler as a go-to resource for information and thought leadership with top media outlets like Yahoo Finance, Forbes, Money and Fox Business).

Siegel helped execute the launch of the CENTURY 21 National Geographic CreativeWorks documentary, “Home Rediscovered,” which illustrated how the COVID-19 pandemic affected lives and changed what people look for in a home. With her team, she secured key influencers like former U.S. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro to appear alongside real-life home buyers and sellers in the film. The documentary sought to avoid coming across as a CENTURY 21 commercial, but as a piece of content that told a story of American life.

Passionate about diversity, equity and inclusion, and as a Latina herself, Siegel has worked to develop, execute and promote CENTURY 21’s Empowering Latinas program, which awarded 121 Latina entrepreneurs with funding to secure their real estate licenses and provided support and mentorship to set them on a path towards success.

The program was initially launched in 2018 as a local market effort, but working closely with her team, Siegel was able to elevate the program to a national level in the past year. Speaking with many of the winners let Siegel see for herself the positive impact the program has had on their lives and how it helped them build generational wealth and provide crucial opportunities to Hispanic communities.

On top of her day-to-day role, Siegel leads the corporate team in community service work.

Congrats to Erin Siegel.

Manager, Org Change and Engagement

Ontario Northland

Renée Baker leads the charge in change management at Ontario Northland

The company’s first employee engagement survey was an overwhelming success, followed by action to show the company’s commitment. Baker is a Dynamic Do-er in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

When Ontario Northland, a 120-year-old transportation provider in northern Ontario, wanted to conduct its first ever employee engagement survey, Renée Baker was tasked with developing the communications approach. Leaders and executives there depend on Baker, manager of organizational change and engagement, to distill and translate opportunities, challenges and initiatives into clear, straightforward messages, so the assignment was right in her wheelhouse.

Within weeks, Baker developed a communication strategy and brand for the inaugural ON Voice employee engagement survey, which received a record response rate of 73% — a huge accomplishment considering 80% of the workforce are non-desk workers, spread across several locations and thousands of miles.

Ontario Northland now had the opportunity to not only listen to and understand its employees’ needs, but to act on the information and show employees that their voices matter. To turn insight into action, Baker and her team used the results from the survey as a foundation to engage employees across all levels the organization.

Connecting across a dispersed workforce was a challenge, especially due to the Ontario Northland landscape and the nature of its demanding and often unpredictable work. Baker included interactive workshops, focus groups, 1:1 conversations, surveys and lunch-and-learns, all customized to stakeholder preferences and delivered across multiple channels (virtual, face-to-face, print).

Baker’s portfolio was recently expanded to include the development of enterprise-wide change management competencies. Her implementation of strategies, methodologies, processes and tools have helped break down silos and embody new ways of working together.

Congrats to Renée Baker.

Manager, Communications

Applebee's Grill + Bar

Batista juggles a variety of roles to keep Applebee’s on the radar

Allegra Batista is in charge of an internal newsletter, video content and social media campaigns for the casual dining brand. Her achievements have made her a Dynamic Do-er in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

As the communications manager for Applebee’s Bar + Grill, Allegra Batista wears many hats. One of her key tasks is collaborating with franchise partners and internal teams (from operations to leadership) to create and distribute the weekly internal newsletter “Core News,” distributed to 600 people each week; she’s responsible for ensuring its timely delivery stuffed with news, updates and information about the Applebee’s brand.

But there’s more: In addition to the weekly newsletter, Batista also is in charge of Team Member video content, which showcases the people who make Applebee’s what it is. Since February 2022, she’s traveled to seven states capturing content at 12 different Applebee’s locations.

On top of that, Batista is charged with growing brand awareness for Applebee’s on social media. The social space was a growth opportunity for the brand, especially among the Gen Z audience, so Batista led agency partners in creative content campaigns that have achieved an average engagement rate of 9% and more than 9.5 million social media impressions.

To position Applebee’s as a player on social media, Batista worked with agency teams to create a 360-campaign featuring the make-out song of the summer, “Taste My Face,” which dropped with the first-ever datable music video on National Wing Day and National Lipstick Day. The earned approach was designed to connect Applebee’s with its existing and newer audiences, and to help singles navigate the pandemic’s side effects on dating, from the halt of in-person dating to the fear of starting out again after months away from the dating scene.

The campaign drew more than 3.4 billion earned impressions, including mentions on The Today Show, Jimmy Fallon and the Drew Barrymore show. Additionally, Applebee’s saw a 5% increase in share of voice, 2.6 times more social brand mentions and eight times more brand engagements. Batista’s approach not only garnered a large number of impressions but reshaped the way Applebee’s appeals to its guests.

Congrats to Allegra Batista.

Senior Director, Global Communications, Culture and Brand Partnerships

Bacardi - PATRÓN Tequila

More buzz for the brand: Allie Bostwick boosted PATRÓN Tequila with collaboration

Enlisting top F1 racers, streetwear designers and music stars helped raise visibility and coverage for PATRÓN. Bostwick’s success has made her an honoree as a Dynamic Do-er in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards.

Allie Bostwick started her career with PATRÓN Tequila as director of public relations in 2019. Now senior director, global communications, culture and brand partnerships, Bostwick has transformed PATRÓN from just a tequila to one of the most buzzed-about brands in culture, music, sports, entertainment and fashion.

Among her recent achievements, Bostwick brought PATRÓN into the world of Formula 1 racing. With the popularity of F1 rising, she established several first-time collaborations for PATRÓN, starting by partnering with Mexican racing icon Sergio “Checo” Perez. From there, Bostwick secured a partnership with F1 Paddock Club™, establishing PATRÓN as the first-ever exclusive tequila partner of the F1 trackside experience.

In addition, at the United States Grand Prix in Austin, PATRÓN won the No. 1 share of voice for earned media and social media, receiving multiple pieces of headline coverage from top-tier media, generating more than 500 million impressions for the brand and further solidifying PATRÓN as the most talked-about tequila brand against its competitors.

Bostwick also led two brand collaborations with famed streetwear designer John Geiger, both of which sold out in minutes. The first, centered around National Tequila Day 2021, featured a limited-edition streetwear collection inspired by PATRÓN Tequila’s annual Mexican Heritage Tin. A second collaboration, with the designer for Cinco de Mayo 2022, featured limited-edition PATRÓN x John Geiger GF-01 sneakers inspired by the brand’s agave fields in Mexico. The campaign won PATRÓN the No. 1 share of voice during this cultural holiday, gaining more than 75 pieces of coverage that generated more than 1.2 billion impressions for the brand.

Most recently, Bostwick led PATRÓN Tequila’s newest and most prestigious product launch to date — PATRÓN EL ALTO. Under Bostwick’s leadership, PATRÓN brought together music legends and innovators like Missy Elliott and Hit-Boy to launch PATRÓN EL ALTO. She spearheaded all aspects of the marketing launch, including the national launch event and securing a partnership that brought Missy Elliot back to the stage for her first live performance in three years.

To date, PATRÓN EL ALTO has garnered 87 placements and 887 million impressions.

Congrats to Allie Bostwick.
